title: The Opal Tower effect: Sydney high-rise site sales crash 50 per cent
text:
Amid funding difficulties, concerns over combustible cladding and construction defects and weaker consumer demand for new apartments, sales of residential development sites plummeted 38 per cent to $5.1 billion in the 2019 financial year.

The slump – from $8.25 billion of sales recorded in fiscal 2018 – was led by Greater Sydney, where the value of sales of development sites suitable for high-density projects (25 or more apartments and more than four storeys) halved to $1.97 billion (out of a state total of $2.7 billion), according to Knight Frank's latest Australian Residential Development Review.

Opal Tower was evacuated in December 2018. Dominic Lorrimer

Development site sales volumes fell 21 per cent in Victoria to $1.9 billion, and fell in all the other mainland states apart from the very small South Australian market, which bucked the national trend with a four-fold rise to $78 million.

Driving the 38 per cent national fall was reduced demand from overseas investors, especially in Sydney, where they accounted for just 11 per cent of total site sales. Across Sydney, average site values fell 12 per cent to $184,000 per apartment, more than double the fall in Melbourne.

The 12-month period covered by the report included the evacuations of the faulty Opal and Mascot Towers in Sydney, a growing national flammable cladding crisis and lack of appetite among the major banks to lend to developers.
description: Sales of development sites suitable for high-density projects in Sydney halved to $1.97 billion, a report by Knight Frank found.
